qas.question: What are the two categories of public funding?

answers.text: direct, which entails a monetary transfer to a party, and indirect

qas.question: Which percentage of nations provide no direct or indirect public funding?
What percentage of nations provide direct funding?
Are parties required to reveal their funding?

answers.text: required to disclose their finances to the Election management body.

qas.question: What percentage of nations provide indirect funding?
What is one type of political party?
Where do you have to broadcast on if you are a member of a direct party?
How many people know about the ACE Electoral Knowledge network?
How many known political parties are there worldwide?
What type of information do over 180 parties disclose to the ACE Electoral Knowledge Network?

context: There are two broad categories of public funding, <a0_0><b5_0>direct<b5_0/>, which entails a monetary transfer to a party, and indirect<a0_0/>, which includes broadcasting time <b6_0>on state media<b6_0/>, use of the mail service or supplies. According to the Comparative Data from the ACE Electoral Knowledge Network, out of a sample of <b8_0>over 180<b8_0/> nations, <a1_0>25%<a1_0/> of nations provide no direct or indirect public funding, <a2_0><b7_0>58%<b7_0/><a2_0/> provide direct public funding and <a4_0>60%<a4_0/> of nations provide indirect public funding. Some countries provide both direct and indirect public funding to political parties. Funding may be equal for all parties or depend on the results of previous elections or the number of candidates participating in an election. Frequently parties rely on a mix of private and public funding and are <a3_0>required to disclose <b9_0>their finances<b9_0/> to the Election management body.
